article.headline: Why gold has become a âweapon of choiceâ for investors
article.body: Gold prices have climbed to their highest levels in nearly nine years, with the precious metal seen as a âweapon of choiceâ for gold investors dealing with pandemic-related uncertainty in the stock market, clearing the path to a fresh record in the second half of the year. In Wednesday trading, the most-active August gold futures contract US:GCQ20 Â was up $13.20, or 0.7%, at $1,823.10 an ounce after tapping a high of $1,829.80. Futures prices havenât traded or settled at levels this high since September 2011. The settlement record for most-active gold futures stands at $1,891.90 from Aug. 22, 2011, based on records going back to November 1984, according to Dow Jones Market Data. The record intraday level was seen at $1,923.70 an ounce on Sept. 6, 2011. Gold breezed through the $1,800 level and âseems to have recovered its mojo,â said Ross Norman, chief executive officer of precious metals news and information provider Metals Daily. Bulls will also be âmuch encouraged that silver is performing at last.â September silver US:SIU20 Â was up 44.1 cents, or 2.4%, at $19.14 an ounce in Wednesday dealings. Itâs poised for the highest most-active contract settlement since September 2019. Norman told MarketWatch that gold is âneither responding to either the U.S. dollar nor the virus, but the second quarter economic impact,â with massive M2 money [supply] growth leading to concerns about future inflation, debt and negative real yield on U.S. Treasurys. M2 is a key measure for U.S. money supply. “ âThe weapon of choice has clearly been the gold ETF and purchases year to date have exceeded anything seen in any previous full year.â ” â Ross Norman, Metals Daily To gain exposure to gold, âthe weapon of choice has clearly been the gold ETF and purchases year to date have exceeded anything seen in any previous full year,â said Norman. The World Gold Council said that global net inflows for gold-backed exchange-traded funds reached $39.5 billion, topping the previous annual inflow record of $23 billion from 2016, according to a report issued Tuesday. North American funds accounted for 80% of the global net inflows in June, adding $4.6 billion in assets under management. âGold ETF investment demand shattered numerous records this year as investors sought safety from the economic turmoil created by COVID-19,â Juan Carlos Artigas, head of research at the World Gold Council, said in a statement. Gold ETF investment demand is likely to continue its âstrong momentumâ in the second half of the year as concerns over the economic impact of COVID-19 and infection rates of the virus linger, he added. Year to date, most-active gold futures trade higher by nearly 19%. Ed Moy, who was director of the U.S. Mint from 2006 to 2011, during the financial crisis, said that many of the same factors that lifted gold from around $600 in 2006 to $1,900 in 2011 are leading the current rise in gold prices. Thereâs a âhuge amount of monetary and fiscal stimulus without a clear path to unwind and an uncertain and choppy path to recovery from an unprecedented economic crisis,â Moy, who is currently chief strategist at gold retailer Valaurum, told MarketWatch. âThis has caused a flight to safety and fear of inflation, which has benefitted gold.â Still, there are some differences between today and the 2006 to 2011 period of the Great Recession. Among those, âthe amount of both monetary and fiscal stimulus is, and will be, greater in magnitude and done in a shorter time period,â said Moy. âDomestic protests, riots and unrest, and the upcoming presidential election cast uncertainty over the traditional view of the U.S. being an island of stability during an economic storm.â The pandemic, meanwhile, has âcaused government mints who produce precious metal bullion coins to partially or fully shut down production on a periodic basis due to COVID infections in their manufacturing plants,â disrupting normal supply chains to the mints, he said. Gold prices may still see some downward pressure from profit takers, warned Moy, but fundamentals indicate that higher gold prices ahead. âWe have a long uncertain road ahead to recovery and that will be gold for gold prices.â As for how high prices may go, Norman said his forecast issued to the London Bullion Market Association in December 2019 still stands, calling for a 2020 high of $2,080 an ounce for gold.
